Name: Report on the trafficking of illegal firearms.
Title: A Local Law to amend the administrative code of the city of New York, in relation to a report on the trafficking of illegal firearms

History.Description: This Introduction was Introduced by Council
This Introduction was Referred to Comm by Council to the Committee on Public Safety

Summary: This bill would require the Mayor’s Office to Prevent Gun Violence to coordinate with the Police Department to conduct a study and submit a report on the illegal transportation of firearms. The study and report would need to identify the locations where firearms have been seized or surrendered in the City, and specifically the locations where firearms that have been connected to a crime have been seized or surrendered in the City, including the type of firearm, the manufacturer of the firearm, and whether the firearm is a ghost gun or 3-D printed firearm. The study and report would also need to identify the ways states and municipalities coordinate to prevent the illegal transportation of firearms, recommendations for states and municipalities to increase collaboration to prevent the illegal transportation of firearms, and recommendations for federal, state and municipal policies to prevent the illegal transportation of firearms.

\pard\ltrpar\fi720\sl480\slmult1\qj Section 1. Chapter 3 of title 10 of the administrative code of the city of New York is amended by adding a new section 10-315 to read as follows:\par
\cf1\ul\'a7 10-315 Firearm trafficking report. a. \cf0 Definitions. As used in this local law, the term \ldblquote firearm\rdblquote  has the same meaning ascribed to such term in subdivision 1 of section 10-301.\par
\cf1 b.\cf0  Report. The office to prevent gun violence shall coordinate with the police department to conduct a study on reducing the flow of firearms into the city and shall submit a report to the mayor and the speaker of the council no later than December 1, 2022, and annually thereafter. Such study and report shall include: \par
1. For each firearm that is seized or surrendered in the city and obtained by the police department:\par
(a) Whether the firearm was connected to a crime;\par
(b) Where the firearm originated, including where it was first sold, manufactured, imported or assembled;\par
(c) The date such firearm was last sold;\par
(d) The location where such firearm entered the city, and the method of transportation into the city, including whether the firearm entered through a roadway or a sea port;\par
(e) The location where the firearm was seized or surrendered and obtained by the police department;\par
(f) The type of such firearm;\par
(g) The manufacturer or importer of such firearm; \par
(h) Whether the firearm is a ghost gun or a firearm created using a three-dimensional printer, and if so the entities that produced such firearm or parts thereof;\par
(i) The dealer of such firearm and whether such dealer is licensed; and\par
(j) Whether the firearm is registered in any registry, including the national firearms registration and transfer record; \par
2. A review of the ways firearms are illegally transported into the city, including through roadways on and connected to interstate 95 and sea ports or bodies of water;\par
3. A review of the ways states and municipalities collaborate to prevent illegal transportation of firearms, and recommendations to strengthen such collaboration, including: \par
(a) Recommendations for strengthening the collaboration between the office to prevent gun violence, the police department and the bureau of alcohol, tobacco, firearms and explosives and other relevant state and federal agencies;\par
(b) Recommendations for strengthening law enforcement\rquote s ability to trace firearms, including whether increased microstamping would be feasible and effective;\par
(c) Recommendations for implementing a shared electronic tracking system to identify dealers who have sold a particular firearm; and\par
(d) Examining the value of establishing a firearm dealer code of conduct, including recommendations for provisions that should be included in such dealer code of conduct;\par
4. Recommendations for policies to prevent access to firearms by individuals who are likely to harm themselves or others;\par
5. Recommendations for youth programming to discourage the use of firearms by minors; and\par
6. Recommendations for crime prevention through environmental design improvements, including additional lighting in public spaces.\par
\cf1\ulnone\'a7 2. \cf0 This local law takes effect immediately.\par
